metadata.title: Ce/SBA-15 as a heterogeneous ozonation catalyst for efficient mineralization of dimethyl phthalate

IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8751 S1381-1169(13)00180-5 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.04.032 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Characterizations of the catalysts. (a) Low angle XRD patterns of SBA-15 and Ce/SBA-15, (b) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of SBA-15 and Ce/SBA-15, and (c) UV–vis patterns of Ce/SBA-15 and CeO2. Fig. 2 Variations of DMP and TOC removal in ozonation and catalytic ozonation processes. Ozone dose: 100mgh−1, flow rate of oxygen: 1.2Lmin−1, catalyst dose (if use): 0.26g, initial concentration of DMP solution: 10mgL−1, volume of DMP solution: 1.3L, temperature: 25°C, pH≈5.7. Fig. 3 Influence of reaction temperature on TOC removal. Ozone dose: 100mgh−1, flow rate of oxygen: 1.2Lmin−1, catalyst dose: 0.26g, initial concentration of DMP solution: 10mgL−1, volume of DMP solution: 1.3L, pH≈5.7. Ce/SBA-15 as a heterogeneous ozonation catalyst for efficient mineralization of dimethyl phthalate Huihua Yan Ping Lu ⁎ Zhaoqi Pan Xi Wang Qiuyun Zhang Laisheng Li ⁎ School of Chemistry & Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China School of Chemistry & Environment, South China Normal University Guangzhou 510006 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 20 39310185; fax: +86 20 39310187. Graphical abstract The cerium-loaded SBA-15 (Ce/SBA-15) was synthesized successfully and first used as a heterogeneous catalyst for ozonation of DMP. It showed high catalytic activity for efficient mineralization of dimethyl phthalate in catalytic ozonation process. Under the optimal conditions, a high mineralization efficiency of 88.7% was achieved by Ce/SBA-15/O3 process at 60min, 2.6 times higher than SBA-15/O3, 3.5 times higher than O3 alone. Ce/SBA-15 kept a good catalytic activity and stability, and it was a promising catalyst for ozonation process. The catalytic activity of cerium-loaded SBA-15 (Ce/SBA-15) for the ozonation of dimethyl phthalate (DMP) in aqueous solution was studied. Ce/SBA-15 was prepared and characterized by a low angle X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption–desorption and ultraviolet–visible diffuse reflection spectrum (UV–vis DRS). The results showed that the material retained a highly ordered mesoporous structure and processed large surface area. The presence of Ce/SBA-15 slightly accelerated DMP decomposition, but significantly improved its mineralization efficiency. Under the chosen condition, a high mineralization efficiency (88.7%) was achieved by Ce/SBA-15/O3 process at 60min, 2.6 times higher than SBA-15/O3, 3.5 times higher than O3 alone. The comparison among different process indicated that the combination of Ce/SBA-15 and O3 exhibited a significant synergetic effect. Ce/SBA-15 significantly improved ozone decomposition into hydroxyl radicals in aqueous solution and the oxidation of DMP occurred via the free radical mechanism. The reused experiment verified that Ce/SBA-15 kept a good catalytic activity and stability, and it was a promising heterogeneous catalyst. Keywords Ce/SBA-15 Catalytic ozonation Dimethyl phthalate 1 Introduction Phthalate acid esters (PAEs) are widely used as plasticizers in many industrial products to improve their flexibility and durability. But many phthalates are suspected to be teratogens, mutagens, hepatotoxic agents and endocrine disruptors, and they can lead to adverse effects on organisms even in a low concentration [1,2]. They have become ubiquitous environmental pollutants and been found in diverse environmental samples, including surface marine waters, freshwaters and sediments [3]. The short-chained dimethyl phthalate (DMP), a most frequently identified PAEs, is widespread in the environment because of its common usage and refractory biodegradability [4]. It has been listed as an environmental priority pollutant for its toxicity [5]. So its removal has drawn great attention from researchers in recent years. The most common method for phthalates removal from wastewater is biological treatment, including aerobic and anaerobic conditions [6]. DMP is phthalate with low biodegradability, so there is a strong need to look for an effective treatment process for its removal. In recent years, DMP treatment has been focused on the application of various advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), such as UV/H2O2 [1], Fenton/UV [7] and Ru/Al2O3/O3 [8]. Heterogeneous catalytic ozonation, a kind of novel AOPs, has received increasing attention due to its potentially high effectiveness in degrading refractory organic pollutants without high reaction temperature and pressure and low negative effect on water quality [9]. The major advantage of heterogeneous catalytic system compared to homogeneous is the ease of catalyst retrieval and can be reused after some pre-treatments [10]. But the choice of catalyst is critical for catalytic ozonation process. Nowadays, mesoporous materials have been attracted much attention in the field of adsorption and catalysis for their high surface area and relative high thermal stability [11]. They have been widely explored as catalyst supports because their high surface area can facilitate the development of higher metal dispersions. Among many kinds of mesoporous silica's such as MCM-41 and SBA-15, SBA-15 has attracted much attention due to its larger pores, thicker walls and much higher hydrothermal stability than those of MCM-41 [12]. But pure silica SBA-15 shows very limited catalytic activities due to the lack of lattice defect, redox properties, basicity and acidity [13]. Hence it needs to be introduced with active sites to improve its catalytic activity. In recent years, SBA-15 modified with different metals such as vanadium, cobalt and lanthanide have been studied [13–15], but their catalytic activity for ozonation of phthalic acid esters in aqueous solution was scarcely reported. In our previous research, SBA-15 has been loaded by iron and proven to be an efficient ozonation catalyst [16]. Nevertheless, iron-leaching was found during catalytic ozonation process. It is known that the metal leaching affects the stability of catalyst in ozonation process, so further research for more efficient catalysts is of great importance. It has been reported that cerium oxide is insoluble in water [17]. And cerium-containing materials are powerful one-electron oxidants, which have been used as catalysts for the selective oxidation of organic reagents [18–20]. Cerium oxide prepared by precipitation from Ce(III) salt aqueous solutions can result in CeO2 containing traces of Ce(III) [21,22], which are thought to be necessary for promoting the decomposition of O3 into hydroxyl radicals by redox reactions on the catalyst surface. However, only a few studies have reported cerium-containing catalysts for ozonation of organic pollutants. In our previous work, cerium supported on activated carbon was prepared and it showed high catalytic activity for ozonation of DMP [23]. But activated carbon was easily oxidized by ozone, which limited its use in ozonation process [24]. In this work, SBA-15 was modified by cerium using Ce(NO3)3·6H2O as cerium precursor and it was applied in catalytic ozonation of DMP. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials and reagents The triblock copolymer EO20PO70EO20 (Pluronic P123, MW=5800) was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) and cerous oxide (CeO2) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Dimethyl phthalate (DMP), tert-butanol (TBA), hydrochloric acid (HCl), sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Agent Factory (Tianjin, China). All chemicals were analytical grade. The pH value of the solution was adjusted by H2SO4 and NaOH. 2.2 Preparation of SBA-15 and Ce/SBA-15 SBA-15 was synthesized according to a hydrothermal method as described by Huang et al. [16]. Briefly, 4.0g P123 was dispersed in 125mL 2M HCl solution at 40°C, followed by the addition of 8.0g TEOS with stirring. The mixture was continuously stirred for 24h at 40°C, then transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and aged for 48h at 100°C. The product was then filtered, washed, and dried at 80°C. Then the sample was calcined at 550°C in air for 6h to get SBA-15. Ce/SBA-15 samples were prepared according to an incipient wetness impregnation method using Ce(NO3)3·6H2O as cerium precursor [25]. SBA-15 was first dried at 80°C for 12h. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in deionized water at a concentration that depended on the desired metal loading. Then proper amount of SBA-15 was dispersed into cerium solution under ultrasonic vibration for 90min. After impregnation, the mixture was dried at 80°C and then calcined in air at 550°C for 3h to get Ce/SBA-15. 2.3 Catalytic ozonation procedure The catalytic reaction procedure was carried out in a 1.3L cylindrical reactor (h =500mm, Φ in =60mm) made of borosilicate glass. Ozone (100mgh−1 output) was produced in situ from pure oxygen (1.2Lmin−1) by a DHX-SS-1G ozone generator (made in China) and fed to the solution through a porous glass plate at the bottom of the reactor. The excess ozone in the outlet gas was trapped by a Na2S2O3 solution. The reaction was maintained at desirable temperatures by circulating water from a thermostatic bath (SDC-6, Ningbo, China). 1.3L DMP solution (10mgL−1) and 0.26g catalyst were added into the reactor. Water samples were taken at regular intervals to analyze DMP and total organic carbon (TOC) concentration. The 5% Na2S2O3 solution was used to quench the continuous ozonation reaction in the samples. 2.4 Analytical procedures XRD measurements of the samples were carried out using Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ ranges of 0.6–3.0° (low angle) on a BRUKER D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were carried out at 77K on a Quantasorb surface area analyzer (Micromeritics, ASAP2020, USA). UV–vis DRS was recorded on a Cary 5000 spectophtometer using BaSO4 pellet. Water samples were first filtered by a 0.45μm prefilter. DMP concentration was quantified with a high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, LC10A, Shimadzu, Japan) using a Diamonsil 5U C18 column (250mm×4.6mm, Dikma technologies). The wavelength of UV/visible detector (SPD – 10AV) was set at 254nm. The mobile phase was composed of methanol and water at 70:30 (v:v) with flow rate controlled at 1.0mLmin−1. TOC was analyzed by TOC analyzer (TOC-Vwp, Shimadzu, Japan). The concentration of leaching cerium was detected by the inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Thermo Scientific, IRIS Intrepid IIXSP, USA). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts As observed in Fig. 1a, XRD patterns of SBA-15 and Ce/SBA-15 presented three well-resolved peaks at (100), (110) and (200), which are characteristic of mesoporous material with 2D-hexagonal structure [12]. The peaks of Ce/SBA-15 were almost the same as that of SBA-15, indicating that Ce/SBA-15 retained a highly ordered mesoporous structure after a loading process. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of SBA-15 and Ce/SBA-15 were shown in Fig. 1b, they were type IV with hysteresis loop, which is typical for mesoporous materials with 2D-hexagonal structure [12]. The pore size distributions showed that the samples had narrow pore size distributions although Ce/SBA-15 exhibited slightly wider pore size distribution than SBA-15, indicating that Ce/SBA-15 retained uniform and narrow mesorporous structure of SBA-15. Table 1 summarized the textural properties of the materials. The surface areas gradually decreased after Ce loading on SBA-15 with the increasing Ce content from 1.0% to 4.0%. It was attributed to the existence of cerium species in the channels, but Ce/SBA-15 (1.0% content) still maintained a large surface area of 656.33m2 g−1. The UV–vis patterns of Ce/SBA-15 and CeO2 were shown in Fig. 1c. It could be seen that CeO2 had a strong absorption band around 200–350nm, and Ce/SBA-15 also showed an absorption band around 250nm, indicating that CeO2 was contained in Ce/SBA-15. The actual Ce content in Ce/SBA-15 was detected and shown in Table 2 . As observed, the results were not consistent with theoretical contents, but there existed some relation, the actual content of all samples were almost two-fifths of the theory content, indicating that the incipient wetness impregnation is a relatively stable method for preparing the catalysts. 3.2 Decomposition of DMP by ozonation and catalytic ozonation Fig. 2 provided DMP and TOC removal-time profile for ozonation and catalytic ozonation of DMP. As observed, ozonation alone was a feasible technology to decompose DMP, achieving up to 98% DMP removal in 15min. It was because that DMP is a compound that composes a benzene ring with methyl ester groups, which are highly reactive with ozone, so it can be quickly decomposed in oxidation system. But TOC removal was unsatisfied, only slight mineralization efficiency (20.6%) was reached at 60min. It may be related to the fact that ozone is a strong oxidation agent but its oxidation is selective, and the performance is often not strong enough to remove the organics by direct mineralization in a reasonable time [26]. When SBA-15 was added into the ozonation process, only a slight improvement of TOC removal by 10.5% was attained at 60min, indicating that SBA-15 had low catalytic activity and it needs to be introduced with active sites to improve the catalytic activity. When Ce/SBA-15 was added into the ozonation process, significant improvement of DMP mineralization efficiency was achieved. As observed, the maximum TOC removal (88.4%) in 60min was obtained in presence of Ce/SBA-15/O3 (1.0% cerium content), only 31.1% with SBA-15. Ce/SBA-15 showed high catalytic activity for efficient mineralization of DMP. The heterogeneous catalytic ozonation process is very complex which involves gas, liquid and solid phases, and the catalyst plays an important role in the ozonation process. So experiment was carried out to study the effect of active component content on catalytic ozonation process, and find out the catalyst with optimal loading content. As shown in Fig. 2, TOC removals gradually increased with the cerium content from 0.25% to 1.0% and then slightly depressed from 1.0% to 4.0%. Since cerium has been used as catalyst, it was believed that surface active sites of the catalyst increase with cerium content on SBA-15 [16,18], so the mineralization efficiency increased. However, overloaded cerium species would enhance steric hindrance and decrease the catalyst surface area (confirmed by Table 1) [23], and lead to the depression of catalytic activity. So the optimal loading content was 1.0%, which showing the highest catalytic activity for efficient mineralization of DMP, and it was employed in the following experiment. 3.3 The optimization of reaction parameters 3.3.1 Reaction temperature The reaction temperature is an important factor which influences the reaction rate and ozone solubility in aqueous solution [27]. The increase of temperature can enhance activation molecules leading to improvement of degradation efficiency but decrease ozone solubility in aqueous solution resulting in decrease of degradation efficiency [28]. The effect of temperature depends on the combined result of the two opposing effects. Consequently, there must be an optimum temperature for efficient mineralization of DMP in catalytic ozonation process. As shown in Fig. 3 , the effect of this variable was positive relevant to temperature from 5°C to 35°C, not only for DMP removal, but also for TOC removal. It led to an increase of TOC removal from 28.2% to 88.7% at 60min. This result was mostly due to the increase of chemical reaction rate constant with the temperature, not only for ozone decomposition but also for organics degradation. Although ozone solubility in water decreased with the rising temperature, ozone decomposition was accelerated and it generated more radicals, leading to the improvement of DMP and TOC removal. In order to study the effect of reaction temperature on the kinetics of catalytic ozonation, the data of TOC was fitted by first-order kinetics and the result was shown in Table 3 . The good linearity suggested that the mineralization was of apparent first-order kinetics. Rate constant with 35°C (0.039min−1) was the highest, corresponding with the highest DMP and TOC removal. Therefore, the optimum temperature was 35°C, which was employed in the following experiment. 3.3.2 Initial pH The pH value of solution can affect the surface properties of catalyst [17], the decomposition rate of dissolved ozone and the generation rate of free radicals [29]. So it is necessary to study this factor and determined the optimum pH for catalytic ozonation of DMP. The result was shown in Fig. 4 . It was found that increasing initial pH from acidity to basicity led to a remarkable enhancement on DMP and TOC removal. It was due to the contribution of oxidation by radicals, corresponding to a well-known phenomenon that ozone decomposition constant is strongly dependent on pH and increases with pH [30,31]. As shown from Eqs. (1) to (4), an increasing pH would yield more hydroxyl radicals, which is beneficial for organics decomposition [32,33]. (1) O3 +H2O→2HO +O2 (2) O3 +OH− →O2 − +HO2 (3) O3 +HO →O2 +HO2 ↔O2 − +H+ (4) O3 +HO2 ↔2O2 +HO Apart from OH−, the presence of catalysts can also facilitate the decomposition of ozone [34]. As shown from Eqs. (5) to (8), the protonated ( M-O H 2 + ) or deprotonated ( M-O − ) of the oxide surface, depending on the pH value of solution, would be beneficial for the production of radicals [30,35,36]. But TOC removal was unsatisfied at pH 3.0 because the pH value strongly influenced the stability of catalyst for the leaching of effective component. As shown in Table 4 , the leaching of cerium increased with solution acidity, and the maximum cerium leaching (0.487mgL−1) was obtained at pH 3.0, causing the lowest TOC removal, while others were less than 0.200mgL−1. So TOC removal dramatically increased with pH from 3.0 to 5.7. While further increased to pH 9.0, a slight reduction of TOC removal was observed. The negative effect may be due to the chain termination step as displayed in Eq. (9) [9]. So the optimum pH value of the solution was 5.7. (5) M-OH2 + +O3 →M-OH + +HO3 (6) M-OH + +H2O→M-OH2 + +HO (7) M-O− +O3 →M-O2 − +O2 (8) M-O2 − →M+O2 − (9) HO +HO2 →H2O+O2 3.4 Mechanism of catalytic ozonation of DMP 3.4.1 Relationship between ozone and catalyst In order to study the relationship between ozone and Ce/SBA-15, comparison of DMP and TOC removal among different processes was carried out under the optimal condition (35°C, pH=5.7). As observed in Fig. 5 , DMP was quickly removed from the oxidation system, but only slight mineralization efficiency (25.2%) was reached at 60min in O3 process. In SBA-15/O3 and CeO2/O3 process, a slight improvement of TOC removal by 9.0% and 13.4% was attained at 60min. The adsorptions of DMP by SBA-15, Ce/SBA-15 and CeO2 were also studied. Their adsorptions were from 4.9% to 5.9% in equilibrium, indicating that the adsorptions could be neglected. If O3 oxidation and Ce/SBA-15 adsorption worked separately, only 30.13% TOC removal (25.2% ozone oxidation and 4.93% adsorption) was obtained in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process. However, a significant improvement of TOC removal was achieved when Ce/SBA-15 was added, increasing up to 88.7% at 60min. So it could be concluded that there was a significant synergetic effect in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process for TOC removal in aqueous solution. The apparent kinetics data of these oxidation processes was studied and the results indicated that the mineralation of DMP followed pseudo-second-order kinetics. The rate constant of TOC degradation in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process was the highest, reaching 0.019Lmg−1 min−1, only 0.0007Lmg−1 min−1 with O3 alone, 0.0011Lmg−1 min−1 with SBA-15/O3, 0.0014Lmg−1 min−1 with CeO2/O3. The results suggested that Ce/SBA-15 was a promising catalyst for efficient mineralization of DMP. It is well known that the catalytic ozonation is always related to the interaction between catalyst and ozone. Ozone interaction with the metal oxide surface results in the formation of free radicals, which can initiate radical chain reactions both on the surface of the catalyst and in the liquid phase [22]. In order to study this interaction, the effect of Ce/SBA-15 on the decomposition of ozone in liquid solution was tested and shown in Fig. 6 . As shown in Fig. 6(a), ozone concentration reached equilibrium after 30min in both O3 alone and Ce/SBA-15/O3 process. And the equilibrium ozone concentration in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process was much lower than that in O3 process. It was corresponding to the results that the presence of Ce/SBA-15 significantly increased TOC removal. Since intermediate products of the oxidized DMP produced by ozone were reluctant to react with ozone but active to react with radical generated by ozone, ozone concentration significantly decreased in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process. In order to further study the relation between catalyst and ozone, ozone concentration in aqueous solution without DMP was also tested. As observed from Fig. 6(b), the variation tendency of ozone concentration was familiar with that of Fig. 6(a), and adding catalyst obviously decreased the ozone concentration when compared to O3 alone. So it could be deduced that the addition of Ce/SBA-15 significantly increased ozone decomposition into hydroxyl radicals and reduced ozone equilibrium concentration in aqueous solution. 3.4.2 Effect of hydroxyl radical scavenger Since DMP adsorption on Ce/SBA-15 was very weak and the direct ozone oxidation of TOC was quite slow (confirmed by Fig. 5), the enhanced TOC degradation by the catalytic ozonation is possibly ascribed to accelerated hydroxyl radical generation from ozone. In order to evaluate whether catalytic ozonation of DMP with Ce/SBA-15 as a catalyst follows the hydroxyl radical reaction mechanism, the effect of TBA (a strong hydroxyl radical scavenger) on catalytic ozonation was studied and shown in Fig. 7 . At 15min oxidation time, DMP removal efficiency reached 98% without TBA, only 83% with the presence of 5mgL−1 TBA, 70% with 10mgL−1 TBA, indicating that the catalytic ozonation process involved hydroxyl radical and it was dominated by hydroxyl radical oxidation mechanism. So it could be deduced that the oxidation mechanism of DMP in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process occurred via hydroxyl radicals in the liquid bulk. 3.4.3 Variation of pH during ozonation and catalytic ozonation To further investigate catalytic ozonation of DMP, changes of pH in ozonation and catalytic ozonation process were measured and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . The pH decreased from 5.70 to 4.20 at first 15min in all processes. Then it slightly declined to 4.11 at 60min in O3 process, but increased to 4.66 in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process. It was mainly related to the mineralization degree of small molecule acid intermediate products. The ozone dipolar cyclo-addition of the benzene ring is considered to be the major oxidation pathway of DMP because the two methyl carboxylate groups are strongly electron-withdrawing and deactivate to the electrophilic substitution reaction [37]. The initial attack on DMP during ozonation process was to via the electrophilic addition to form phenols–quinones–aromatic acids, then the aromatic rings were broken down to form short-chain organic acids such as formic acid and oxalic acid, which are reluctant to react with ozone, so the pH decreased first and then kept stable in O3 process. When Ce/SBA-15 was added to the ozonation process, there were many possible sites (such as alkyl chain and aromatic ring) for radicals to attack, and the short-chain organic acids were further decomposed into CO2 and H2O eventually, so pH increased to 4.66 at 60min in Ce/SBA-15/O3 process, achieving efficient mineralization of DMP. 3.5 Stability of Ce/SBA-15 In order to test the catalyst's stability, the recycling experiments were performed with repeated use of Ce/SBA-15 and the result was shown in Table 5 . It was found that DMP removal nearly kept stable while TOC removal slightly decreased from 88.7% to 82.6% at 60min with the reused time. It might be caused by the leaching of cerium. As shown in Table 5, a little leaching of cerium from the catalyst was found in the reaction mixture at 60min. 0.175mgL−1 cerium leaching was observed at first time, and the others were less than 0.1mgL−1. Although a little leaching of cerium was found, the catalytic capacity of Ce/SBA-15 was hardly affected. In order to investigate the difference between the fresh and reused catalyst, the SEM images of Ce/SBA-15 before and after used were tested and the result was shown in Fig. 9 . As observed, the particle morphologies of the samples were almost the same. No significantly change for new or used Ce/SBA-15 was found, corresponding to the good activity and stability of Ce/SBA-15. So it could be concluded that Ce/SBA-15 kept a good stability and recyclability in catalytic ozonation of DMP, and it was an optional heterogeneous ozonation catalyst for efficient mineralization of DMP. 4 Conclusion Highly ordered Ce/SBA-15 was prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method and it retained the structure of SBA-15 and processed large surface area (656.33m2 g−1). Ce/SBA-15 showed the high catalytic activity for efficient mineralization of DMP in ozonation process. The cerium content, reaction temperature and initial pH of DMP solution played important roles in catalytic ozonation process. Under the optimal conditions (1.0% cerium content, 35°C, pH=5.7), TOC removal reached 88.7% at 60min, only 34.2% with SBA-15/O3, 38.6% with CeO2/O3, and 25.2% with ozonation alone. The combination of Ce/SBA-15 and O3 exhibited a significant synergetic effect. Ce/SBA-15 significantly improved ozone decomposition into hydroxyl radicals in aqueous solution and reduced ozone concentration in equilibrium. The oxidation mechanism of DMP occurred via hydroxyl radicals in liquid bulk. The reused experiment showed that Ce/SBA-15 kept a good catalytic activity and stability, and it was a promising catalyst for ozonation process. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic activity of cerium-loaded SBA-15 (Ce/SBA-15) for the ozonation of dimethyl phthalate (DMP) in aqueous solution was studied. Ce/SBA-15 was prepared and characterized by a low angle X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), nitrogen adsorption–desorption and ultraviolet–visible diffuse reflection spectrum (UV–vis DRS). The results showed that the material retained a highly ordered mesoporous structure and processed large surface area. The presence of Ce/SBA-15 slightly accelerated DMP decomposition, but significantly improved its mineralization efficiency. Under the chosen condition, a high mineralization efficiency (88.7%) was achieved by Ce/SBA-15/O3 process at 60min, 2.6 times higher than SBA-15/O3, 3.5 times higher than O3 alone. The comparison among different process indicated that the combination of Ce/SBA-15 and O3 exhibited a significant synergetic effect. Ce/SBA-15 significantly improved ozone decomposition into hydroxyl radicals in aqueous solution and the oxidation of DMP occurred via the free radical mechanism. The reused experiment verified that Ce/SBA-15 kept a good catalytic activity and stability, and it was a promising heterogeneous catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Ce/SBA-15 as a heterogeneous ozonation catalyst for efficient mineralization of dimethyl phthalate
